conversations.content: A New Wind: Part One
One day, the dragon Garuda was awakened by the sound of a young boy's voice. Though she scowled at him most fiercely, the cheerful lad merely asked to know her name.
Garuda was flummoxed, and remained silent for some time— for it turned out she could not even remember her own name.
She had lived all alone atop the bluff for ages, with only the ever-howling wind for company.
At length, she recalled her name and managed to summon forth her voice. ＂I am called Garuda,＂ she rasped. ＂And who are you?＂
＂You're Garuda, huh? I'm Hiram! I live in the village under the cliff.＂
Garuda had not left the bluff in many a year, so it would not have been strange for a village or two to have cropped up beneath it in that period.
＂I was following the wind,＂ continued Hiram, ＂and it led to you. I just wanted to thank you for always giving us such nice breezes!＂
As the boy's words sank in, a new wind softly blew over Garuda's heart.
She had been acknowledged by another; this was a first for Garuda. The way she felt at that moment would be eternally engraved upon her soul.
The boy continued to visit Garuda, and they soon became fast friends. Finally, Hiram invited her to visit the village where he lived.
So Garuda went down to the village with him, for she believed winds of hope were blowing there.
A New Wind: Part Two
Garuda had gone down to the village at Hiram's invitation. And though her heart was filled with expectation, she was at a loss once she actually arrived.
It was little more than a few rows of shabby, dilapidated shacks—and what villagers were there scuttled about with downcast eyes.
＂Fiends attacked us,＂ explained Hiram, as his constant smile dimmed. ＂And the people who left the village to fight them never came back.＂
The new wind in Garuda's heart had healed her deep isolation, and she suddenly felt a similar need to lift the cloud which so clearly hung over Hiram's people.
＂I will save your village,＂ she said. ＂I will bring forth a new wind of protection upon this land.＂
Time passed. And small though the village was, it soon began to grow. Hiram became the chief, unified the villagers, and eventually came to the end of a long and happy life.
Garuda was heartbroken. And after losing her friend, all she had left was the village they had protected and the people who lived in it.
She no longer heard her name spoken by a familiar voice; instead, she was surrounded by trembling voices who called her ＂Lord Garuda.＂ Nonetheless, she still protected them.
One day, a young boy came to visit Garuda's home. It was a moment of happiness she had not known since those days with Hiram, but it passed with the setting of the sun.
Left alone once more, she thought fondly on the warmth of humans and came face-to-face with her present isolation.
It was incredibly painful to return to solitude after having known the joy of existing for the sake of another. Loneliness descended upon Garuda like a squall.
Amidst her sadness, she knew only one truth: No matter how lonely or painful it might have been, it was still better to have met Hiram than to never have known him at all.
A tempest raged over the village that night, and the next day, Garuda demanded that the villagers bring her a sacrifice.
And with that one word, a brother and sister will see their fates tossed about by the indifferent winds.  Ah, but that is a tale for another time.
